Lincoln's adeptness in appointing capable generals and managing military strategy was crucial to the eventual Union victory.

The Emancipation Proclamation, issued on January 1, 1863, declared the freedom of all enslaved people in Confederate-held territory. While it did not immediately free all enslaved individuals, it marked a pivotal moment in the Civil War and set a moral precedent for the abolition of slavery.

One of the most significant impacts of the Emancipation Proclamation is its role in redefining the purpose of the Civil War. Initially framed as a conflict to preserve the Union, Lincoln's proclamation shifted the war’s focus to include the fight against slavery. This transformation laid the groundwork for the eventual passage of the Thirteenth Amendment in 1865, which abolished slavery throughout the United States. The Emancipation Proclamation and the Thirteenth Amendment together created a legal foundation for civil rights, influencing subsequent legislation aimed at promoting equality.

Lincoln’s speeches, particularly the Gettysburg Address, further contributed to the evolving narrative of civil rights. In this address, delivered on November 19, 1863, Lincoln emphasized the principles of human equality and the importance of a government dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. This rhetoric has been invoked by civil rights leaders throughout American history, serving as a moral touchstone for movements advocating for racial equality and justice.

The language of the Emancipation Proclamation has been referenced in various civil rights movements, including the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s.
